starting with an introduction amazon fsx for netapp on tap it's a part
of amazon fsx family of services and for those of you who aren't familiar with amazon fsx it's an aws service we
launched about three and a half years ago that allows customers to launch run and scale feature rich and highly
performant file systems on aws what we have found over the course of the last several years of running different
storage solutions and offering different storage solutions on aws is a lot of customers a lot of data that's
out there today on premises is in the range of hundreds of exabytes of data and is stored predominantly on network
file system now network file storage has been around for a while maybe for decades and in that time there have been
a lot of features and capabilities and functionalities built into network file storage that customers over the years
have adopted they are using it and on which they rely on so a lot of customers that we talked about are excited about
moving to the cloud because they benefit from the scalability and agility that they get running in aws but very often
what we have also heard is customer have a reliance on specific features of uh
the storage solutions that they are currently using so uh let's say for example if a capability acts that i am
used to using on-prem is it available in the cloud and traditionally without uh
having those same capabilities in the cloud migrating has been historically a challenge for certain of their
application and so our goal with fsx as a product is to actually offer fully managed file
storage in aws that offers the feature set performance profiles and data management capabilities that customers
are used to with their existing file system technologies our goal here is to make it easy for any
customers who is looking to move to aws to migrate over to aws without having to reinvent their storage and without
having to think okay so what do i do if i am i don't have that capability in the cloud we are giving customers the full

now fsx is an aws service which means it's fully managed and is supported by

these file system technologies on the best of aws infrastructure to give customers ever increasing price
performance benefits okay so earlier we have got two file

allows customer to launch and run really feature-rich and performant file storages
netapp has historically been an on-prem vendor selling customers file storage hardware with software built into it but
over the last several years they have actually been adopting and pushing for the cloud quite a bit they have been
investing really heavily in the cloud solutions and making ontap available and accessible to customers if they want to

in terms of how simple it makes it to deploy storage okay we have seen a lot of growth with

that have been running on-premise netapp arrays or other type of nas arrays that they want to move to aws and so we have
seen a number of customers make the jump several customers with petabytes of storage migrating to aws having said
that we wanted to talk about customers who migrated to fsx on tap to get the benefits of a fully managed service
which also resulted on their side in reducing the operational overhead so
ehealth is a part of new south wales australian government they have a bunch of medical imaging data that was hosted

setting something up and managing it by themselves was not appealing so being able to get a fully managed provision
file system with a few clicks and uh in the console or super appealing to them
and then all the scalability and the benefits also that comes out of the service what we have here with customers moving
to aws and fsx specific specifically is reduction of operational overhead it
helps enable the customers to focus on the core of their business and a better product to their customers
rather than having to spend a lot of additional time managing infrastructure that's obvious on-prem but even in aws
there comes a point where you don't really want to have to set up and manage the file servers on compute instances
then manage the storage's volumes and then set up replication which is in a different easy altogether so being able
to have us manage all that for them and not having to do patches or updates and continuously keeping the hardware and
software updated behind the scenes is super valuable to the customers with this in mind let's get into the details

users of ontap and some of the benefits of this service for them come down to these
first and foremost making it really easy and quick for these customers to migrate the data to aws knowing that they are

if you are moving from an ontap system to fsx on tap and this is kind of a big deal for a lot of enterprise customers
who have developed operational practices around ontap or who have certified their applications and have a rigorous

another benefit is again everything that customers get from running in the cloud so for a netapp user running on-prem

and to scale with fsx customers get the benefit of being able to deploy a whole new ontap systems in minutes rather than

okay moving on last but not the least we are also seeing a trend actually with a lot of customers where the storage

okay moving on so how does it simplify operations every customer like yourself
is looking to simplify operations there are a lot of benefits that the cloud provides that netapp customers can
now look forward to as a part of migrating to the cloud so one of them is the ability to deploy multi easy storage
that's highly available highly durable this is something that's not very easy to do on prem you need multiple data
centers you need to configure application so with fsx each file system is highly
available and durable across multiple ac's and so what this means is if you look at the bottom of this diagram you
can see a depiction of fsx for ontap file system each file system
has two file servers in two different easys and each file servers has a redundant copy of your data in each easy
as well all of the clients that are mounting your file system at any given point in time are routed automatically
to the active file server in this case the file server is in easy one so let's
say for example there is a failure of that primary file server what happens is automatically amazon fsx fails over to
the other file servers and automatically your clients failover along with it the
clients don't see a disruption fsx is a managed service which means that we are constantly monitoring the
hardware the software powering customers file system and if needed we will replace the field hardware component so
in a matter of minutes fsx would automatically replace it with a new one and clients would automatically fall
back along with it again all of this happens without disruption so from a client perspective they have been just
continuing to read write their data from a highly available network file system
okay same things happen at the disk layer as well so if a disk fails we are automatically detecting replacing field
disk so that you don't need to worry about managing things like radar applications or parity bits or anything
like that to summarize we simplify your operations overhead by providing a fully managed and highly resilient service
okay another thing in the sense of simplicity is all of the integration all of the aws
services that are out there so for netapp customers who are used to running netapp on-prem they are limited in terms
of some of the operational capabilities they have to get more value from that data and in the cloud there are a number
of compute services data management services monitoring services that makes it easy for customers to more quickly
more effectively and more easily gain value from and protect and analyze their data

select their performance and their storage we want to make sure customer don't overpay so what this means is
customers should only be provisioning the storage that they need to store their data and the performance that they need to actually serve their data these
two dimensions are decoupled so customers can independently choose one versus the other
okay on the note of course just wanted to give you a quick overview of some of the cost features features that can
affect cost so fxx for ontap has two storage tiers you have a high
performance ssd tier and we also have a lower cost fully elastic capacity boot
here when i say fully elastic i really mean it so capacity pool storage automatically scales up automatically
scales down based on the data that you have in that tier and what this means is tiering is done automatically for a
typical data set we see that about 20 percent of data that's out there is hot
and about 80 percent of data that's out there is called and so with the combination of these two storage spheres
what customers can do is store a fraction of their data on ssd storage and have ontap automatically tear it off
into a colder data to lower cost onto the lower cost capacity pool storage by doing this they may save a
lot of money also because the tiering is so intelligent and so efficient it will
automatically bring in the data into ssd tier based on the access pattern so to summarize customers can get ssd level of
performance for their workload even if only a fraction of the data is actually residing on the ssd storage at a given

a snapshot at 1pm if i then go ahead and modify a file an hour later let's say at
2 pm what i can actually do is i can right click on that file click on the previous
version tab as you can see in the screenshot here the version of the file that existed at 1pm so this is a really
powerful feature that allows the end user to self-service restoring the files so let's say they accidentally deleted a
file or overload a file this allows the customers to self-service restore without having to talk to an admin
okay so we also offer couple of backup and disaster recovery solutions so one

we also fully support replication capabilities that netapp provides so which are snap mirror and snapwall
